Problem:
Consider the complex function \\( f(z) = e^{z} \\) where \\( z = x + iy \\) in the context of a mapping from the complex plane to itself. We explore the effect of computing the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}[f](\\xi) \\) of this function, where the Fourier transform is defined in the integral form as \\( \\mathcal{F}[f](\\xi) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} f(z) e^{-2\\pi i z \\xi} dz \\).

If an additional operation \\( g(z) = e^{-az} \\) (where \\( a \\) is a positive real constant) is applied before computing \\( \\mathcal{F}[f](\\xi) \\), will the transform \\( \\mathcal{F}[g(f(z))](\\xi) \\) be influenced explicitly by the initial function \\( f(z) = e^{z} \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(z) \\) modifies \\( f(z) \\) to \\( e^{(1 - a)z} \\), and the resultant transformation \\( \\mathcal{F}[g(f(z))](\\xi) \\) therefore is not merely a function of \\( g(z) \\) but a modified version of \\( f(z) \\), reflecting the exponential decay or growth based on the value \\( a \\).
